text:
Happy Wednesday everyone!

I’m curious about how you do *team status updates.*

We’ve got a few of those meetings every week, depending on the team/project we’re in and it just takes time. I’d rather spend that time brainstorming with our team or otherwise discussing projects we just finished.

We’ve tried async status updates in the past when my team was smaller (3), but it kinda fell apart when we grew to a team of 8.

I’m considering giving it a go one more time, but would like to learn if/how you’re doing this in your team.

*What are the tools and rules you use to make status updating effective?*

I’m grateful for all ideas and guidance!

elements.text:
Happy Wednesday everyone!

I’m curious about how you do
team status updates.

We’ve got a few of those meetings every week, depending on the team/project we’re in and it just takes time. I’d rather spend that time brainstorming with our team or otherwise discussing projects we just finished.

We’ve tried async status updates in the past when my team was smaller (3), but it kinda fell apart when we grew to a team of 8.

I’m considering giving it a go one more time, but would like to learn if/how you’re doing this in your team.
What are the tools and rules you use to make status updating effective?
I’m grateful for all ideas and guidance!

text: We have 3 squads of 7 that has one meeting each, and then we have another followup meeting that a representative from each squad attends to update the other squads on what their squad is doing, if there are any opportunities for collaboration etc. If a more important meeting is in someone's calendar then we require a text update to be submitted async

elements.text: We have 3 squads of 7 that has one meeting each, and then we have another followup meeting that a representative from each squad attends to update the other squads on what their squad is doing, if there are any opportunities for collaboration etc. If a more important meeting is in someone's calendar then we require a text update to be submitted async

text: We used Geekbot for async updates for the entire Marketing team and then each individual team (content, performance, offline) had a routine of either a combo Sprint Review/Sprint Planning or 2 distinct meetings, one on a Monday and the other on a Friday. Plus daily stand up, although I’m not a fan if this isn’t for a very specific task force with a very specific goal & deadline.

elements.text: We used Geekbot for async updates for the entire Marketing team and then each individual team (content, performance, offline) had a routine of either a combo Sprint Review/Sprint Planning or 2 distinct meetings, one on a Monday and the other on a Friday. Plus daily stand up, although I’m not a fan if this isn’t for a very specific task force with a very specific goal & deadline.

text:
Thanks for sharing <@U031H7ZKGBS> and <@U02UHL5EX1P>!

I like the idea of weekly check-ins (maybe at the beginning and end of the week) to see how everyone’s doing.

I saw this article from <https://friday.app/p/team-updates|Friday> where they’ve automated this, I’m guessing similar to Geekbot. Now the idea here would be for everyone to see the updates, so that not only the manager sees everything.

Also, I like the idea of text async update, in case you cannot come to the meeting. We’re sometimes left empty-handed if something pops up and a person can’t make it

text: Seems like an obvious one, but we also tend to record the meetings so that if anyone can't attend or if we need to revisit something then we have a reliable copy stored

elements.text: Seems like an obvious one, but we also tend to record the meetings so that if anyone can't attend or if we need to revisit something then we have a reliable copy stored

text: Yea, we do that as well. I just want to make sure we use each others’ time more effectively. Nobody seems to enjoy reporting and ‘reading out loud their jira tasks’ :D

elements.text: Yea, we do that as well. I just want to make sure we use each others’ time more effectively. Nobody seems to enjoy reporting and ‘reading out loud their jira tasks’ :D

text:
That's quite interesting and I've been thinking about it a lot in the past couple of years.

Here's the way I do it (I am co-founder and head of marketing). The company is around 20 people.

1. We do a weekly meeting with the whole team called 'Monday morning meeting' or MMM. Over there we've got themes, so: Product, Marketing, Sales, Design. We usually report what happened last week and what we are going to achieve this week. The meeting has a hard stop of 30 mins and often concludes in 15 mins. The only people talking are the Heads of the departments. 
2. We've got a kind of 'executive meeting' scheduled 3 times per week: Monday, Wednesday, Friday. There is a shared agenda where we write the points we'd like to discuss. If there are no points - we just cancel the meeting. What is important is that this time is *blocked* in our schedule, so if someone needs to discuss something with the other decision makers, they have the opportunity. About 50% of the meetings don't take place. If something doesn't concern your department - you are free to leave the meeting, but nobody does, because it is better to eavesdrop than to be excluded from the conversation. 
3. Finally, I've got *daily standups* with my team - the people that I am responsible for. We get together each morning. This is an extremely important meeting. It kicks off the day for everyone and everyone knows that this is basically.. their last call to actually start working that day (we are fully remote). We have a coffee and discuss the priorities and the tasks for the day (usually happens around 10.30-11AM). People ask for help and then we split into other meeting rooms to collaborate (if needed). This is the time you would spend with your team every day. And you need this quite a lot to set up a remote structure where you build actual relationships with your colleagues. 
Finally, a bit different from those, we've got the quarterly meetings. Each quarter we get together (again some decision-maker meeting) and go over our priorities for the quarter that passed. We analyze, dig deep into the results and try to understand if we under-planned or underestimated something or whatever. This is the most important meeting and its duration is usually 4-5 hours (could be split into 2 days or so). Sounds like a waste of time (and sometimes feel like it during the meeting), but this is the *high level/eagle eye* whatever view of the business and is where *true priorities are set*.

Once we've done that, we create a short presentation for the whole team and get them up to speed with whatever was discussed/decided, share some data, take some time to appreciate everyone's work.

text:
I like the idea of the executive meeting that’s blocked in the calendar!

We had something like this for one of the projects and I like the idea of being able to cancel it with ease, if there are no updates.

As for the MMM and daily stand up routines – I don’t think we could make it work, even in my team. We have people in the US and Europe, some traveling to Asia soon. The time-zone difference would be a big hurdle

text: <@UQ3Q7SQ6A> So it seems that your issue is with the fact that you cannot get everyone on a meeting at the same time... like ever :smile: So the solution to your problem *must be async*, right?

So the solution to your problem
must be async
, right?

text:
Not quite! It’s that everyone’s complaining about having too many meetings and nobody likes reading out their Jira board. And with our time-zones, the meetings usually take place at 2-3pm (6 people of 8 are in the same time zone).

Async status update would actually help us have more time for more creative use of our time.

text:
Hey <@UQ3Q7SQ6A>! We do daily async updates in Teams chat, sharing:
• What we’re working on
• What blockers we have
• What we need from others in the channel
The general rule is to update the chat before 10am. And from there follow-up discussions happen on Teams.

elements.text: Hey
! We do daily async updates in Teams chat, sharing:
What we’re working on
What blockers we have
What we need from others in the channel
The general rule is to update the chat before 10am. And from there follow-up discussions happen on Teams.

text:
If you can't do meetings in the morning you can do end of day meetings (or after lunch meetings). Both work but would have a bit different effect on the team.

We've experimented with the end of day meetings but everyone is quite tired and most people are having a hard time focusing. Therefore, in your case, I'd go for afternoon meetings.

Regarding Jira -> nobody is reading it and no one (but you) will ever read it :smile: Unfortunately, that's just a fact and I'm not even exaggerating.

Unfortunately, that's just a fact and I'm not even exaggerating.

text:
We have a few ways to do updates:
• Weekly team meeting that's a 30 min standup/"how was your weekend" on Monday morning with an agenda for each group to tell folks what they're focused on for the week.
• Monthly planning meeting that's an hour where we look three months ahead, clear away blockers, and have a brainstorm topic that folks submit ahead.  This is all tracked in Notion so folks can update as they go, and we use that page as an agenda for the call.
• My team sends me weekly updates via Lattice (natch) where I gather wins for the week, focus for next week, blockers, and a sentiment for the week. It's helpful in that I get if folks are feeling frustrated/proud/etc and I can jump on things that are slowing the team down.
• We use Asana for all project tracking. So we have all our scheduling for content, socials, emails, videos, etc in there. But it's not really used for Updates.

elements.text: We have a few ways to do updates:
Weekly team meeting that's a 30 min standup/"how was your weekend" on Monday morning with an agenda for each group to tell folks what they're focused on for the week.

Monthly planning meeting that's an hour where we look three months ahead, clear away blockers, and have a brainstorm topic that folks submit ahead.  This is all tracked in Notion so folks can update as they go, and we use that page as an agenda for the call.

My team sends me weekly updates via Lattice (natch) where I gather wins for the week, focus for next week, blockers, and a sentiment for the week. It's helpful in that I get if folks are feeling frustrated/proud/etc and I can jump on things that are slowing the team down.
We use Asana for all project tracking. So we have all our scheduling for content, socials, emails, videos, etc in there. But it's not really used for Updates.

text:
<@U02GLJM8MST> afternoon is doable, later in the evening not so much. Some people have kids to pick up from school/kindergarten + time zone difference. As for Jira :sob: so it’s not just my experience

<@U02UATYAC4X>, I can see that Lattice is like CultureAmp that we use. Are these weekly updates just for you or for the rest of the team as well? I’d like to have something transparent for the entire team. CultureAmp allows for scheduled 1 on 1 where I can actually gather that info, but it only stays visible to me

text:
I have used Lattice before for weekly updates (:wave: <@U02UATYAC4X>!) and it was a great way to sync up with my manager. I've also worked at a fintech and we used our project management tool (Basecamp) to do something similar.

What I've found worked best was having two types of updates (both weekly):

1. An overall status update for the person, shared with the entire team. What did you get done last week? What are you going to work on this week? Are you facing any roadblocks? Because the team was somewhat asynchronous, the update request would go out on Monday and people had to reply within 24 hours. As a manager, it was a way for me to keep a general pulse on the team (managing two teams of 6-7 people) and also provided transparency to teammates.
2. We also did project-level updates, once per week, inside the project management tool. The work was with clients, so the project level update was only for teammates on that project, but talked about any progress, any hurdles, and the client's overall sentiment. The fintech's development team did not use project-level updates, but in retrospect, that likely would have been helpful for long, drawn-out projects.
Hope this helps!

We also did project-level updates, once per week, inside the project management tool. The work was with clients, so the project level update was only for teammates on that project, but talked about any progress, any hurdles, and the client's overall sentiment. The fintech's development team did not use project-level updates, but in retrospect, that likely would have been helpful for long, drawn-out projects.
Hope this helps!

text:
<@UQ3Q7SQ6A> They are really just for me but become a less "task status" oriented update. And it's also a way to share things they perhaps don't feel comfortable sharing with the team, so I wouldn't want the Updates to be shared publicly. Like I've had team members share personal blockers that I've helped with.

For my Monday team meeting where they share their focus areas for the week, I have them add these to an agenda doc, so week to week, they have visibility into what their teammates are doing. And I often go reference this when also surfacing priorities to my manager/dept head.
